newsitem.title: UK: Protection removal in emerging markets needs time.
newsitem.headline: Protection removal in emerging markets needs time.

text.p: The removal of protective tariffs in emerging countries such as India will take some time, Tapan Mitra, Vice-Chairman and and Managing Director of Indian Aluminium Company said.

In a speech prepared for delivery at the Financial Times World Aluminium Conference, Mitra said that the demand for protection sometimes reflects the non-tariff barriers that are sometimes put up by the G-7 countries.

Some of these are continuous shifting demands for quality certification, escalating demands for environment protection and pollution standards, as well as selectively applied censures such as human rights violations and child labour.
"Experience of such barriers, it will be appreciated, cannot make businessmen enthusiastic converts to the idea of a free-market," he said.
In India, the goverment has recently doubled tariff protection for its primary aluminium industry, even though 73 percent of the industry is in the lowest cost group of world smelters.
"In the case of aluminium there is additional concern caused by the significant role of speculative funds in determining price, irrespective of market fundamentals," Mitra said.

The realities of the Indian situation mean that patience is required, due to the competitive practices of the G-7 which needs to be more transparently fair, as well as the uncertainties that invest the London Metal Exchange (LME), he said.
